hints_html: Assume the “if” statement of each answer choice is true. Then evaluate the limit to see if it matches the proposed conclusion.
hints_latex:
Assume the ``if'' statement of each answer choice is true. Then evaluate
the limit to see if it matches the proposed conclusion.
hints_raw: Assume the "if" statement of each answer choice is true. Then evaluate the limit to see if it matches the proposed conclusion.
question: A 03
sols_html:
Let’s test each answer one-by-one:

  • (a) If n < 3 then L = 0.

If n < 3, try a test value of n = 2. Then our limit becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\ &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{- 2 + x^2/x^3 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\ &= -2 \end{aligned}\]

The answer does not match the conclusion L = 0 so this answer is not necessarily true.

  • (b) If n = 3 then L = -2.

If n = 3 then our limit becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^3 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\ &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{-1 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\ &= -1 \end{aligned}\]

The answer does not match the conclusion L = -2 so this answer is not true.

  • (c) If n > 3 and n is odd then”L = ”\(-\infty\)

If n > 3 and n is odd try a test value of n = 5. Then our limit becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^5 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\ &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\ &= \infty \end{aligned}\]

The answer does not match the conclusion \(L = - \infty\), so this answer is not necessarily true.

  • (d) If n > 3 and n is even then”L = ”\(-\infty\).

If n > 3, and even try a test value of n = 4. Then our limit becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^4 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\ &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\ &= -\infty \end{aligned}\]

The answer matches the conclusion \(L = -\infty\) so this answer is correct.

The final answer is (d).
sols_latex:
Let's test each answer one-by-one:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(a)} If \emph{n \textless{} 3} then \emph{L = 0}.
\end{itemize}

If \emph{n \textless{} 3}, try a test value of \emph{n = 2}. Then our
limit becomes:

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{- 2 + x^2/x^3 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -2 
\end{align*}

The answer does not match the conclusion \emph{L = 0} so this answer is
not necessarily true.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(b)} If \emph{n = 3} then \emph{L = -2}.
\end{itemize}

If \emph{n = 3} then our limit becomes:

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^3 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{-1 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -1 
\end{align*}

The answer does not match the conclusion \emph{L = -2} so this answer is
not true.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(c)} If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3} and \emph{n} is odd then''L
  = ''$-\infty$
\end{itemize}

If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3} and \emph{n} is odd try a test value of
\emph{n = 5}. Then our limit becomes:

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^5 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= \infty 
\end{align*}

The answer does not match the conclusion $L = - \infty$, so this answer
is not necessarily true.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(d)} If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3} and \emph{n} is even then''L = ''$-\infty$.
\end{itemize}

If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3}, and even try a test value of \emph{n = 4}.
Then our limit becomes:

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^4 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -\infty 
\end{align*}

The answer matches the conclusion $L = -\infty$ so this answer is
correct.

The final answer is \textbf{(d)}.
sols_raw:
Let's test each answer one-by-one: 

* '''(a)''' If ''n < 3'' then ''L = 0''.

If ''n <  3'', try a test value of ''n = 2''.  Then our limit becomes: 

<math> \begin{align}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{- 2 + x^2/x^3 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -2 \end{align} </math>

The answer does not match the conclusion ''L = 0'' so this answer is not necessarily true.  

* '''(b)''' If ''n = 3'' then ''L = -2''.

If ''n =  3'' then our limit becomes: 

<math> \begin{align}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^3 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{-1 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -1 \end{align} </math>

The answer does not match the conclusion ''L = -2'' so this answer is not true.  

* '''(c)''' If ''n > 3'' and ''n'' is odd then ''L = ''<math>-\infty</math>

If ''n >  3'' and ''n'' is odd try a test value of ''n = 5''.  Then our limit becomes: 

<math> \begin{align}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^5 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^2 - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= \infty \end{align} </math>

The answer does not match the conclusion <math>L = - \infty</math>, so this answer is not necessarily true.
* '''(d)''' If ''n > 3'' and ''n'' is even then ''L = ''<math>-\infty</math>.

If ''n >  3'', and even try a test value of ''n = 4''.  Then our limit becomes: 

<math> \begin{align}
L &= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^4 - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4} \\
&= \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x - 2 + 2/x^3}{1+4/x^3} \\
&= -\infty \end{align} </math>

The answer matches the conclusion <math>L = -\infty</math> so this answer is correct.

The final answer is '''(d)'''.
statement_html:
Which of the following statements concerning the limit below is necessarily true?

\[\begin{aligned} L = \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^n - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4}\end{aligned}\]

  • (a) If n < 3 then L = 0.

  • (b) If n = 3 then L = -2.

  • (c) If n > 3 and n is odd then”L = ”\(-\infty\)

  • (d) If n > 3 and n is even then”L = ”\(-\infty\).
statement_latex:
Which of the following statements concerning the limit below is
necessarily true?

\begin{align*}
L = \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^n - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4}
\end{align*}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(a)} If \emph{n \textless{} 3} then \emph{L = 0}.
\item
  \textbf{(b)} If \emph{n = 3} then \emph{L = -2}.
\item
  \textbf{(c)} If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3} and \emph{n} is odd then''L
  = ''$-\infty$
\item
  \textbf{(d)} If \emph{n \textgreater{} 3} and \emph{n} is even then''L = ''$-\infty$.
\end{itemize}
statement_raw:
Which of the following statements concerning the limit below is necessarily true?

:<math>
L = \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} \frac{x^n - 2x^3 + 2}{x^3+4}
</math>

* '''(a)''' If ''n < 3'' then ''L = 0''.
* '''(b)''' If ''n = 3'' then ''L = -2''.
* '''(c)''' If ''n > 3'' and ''n'' is odd then ''L = ''<math>-\infty</math>
* '''(d)''' If ''n > 3'' and ''n'' is even then ''L = ''<math>-\infty</math>.
